results.title: Australian women's heritage: 1901-1945
results.brief_description: This visual history of Australian women documents the contribution of an often overlooked group. Their work, their mothering and their civilising influence has been a major factor in Australia’s coming of age. Yet women have been receiving second class status from officialdom since the earliest days of Australia’s settlement. This program begins by looking at the reduction in the size of families, the White Australia policy and changes in society’s views on morality. It looks at both World Wars and their impact on Australian women. The contrast between the flappers and the poverty of the 1920’s is interesting to consider. Jewish refugees and British immigrants, votes for women, changes in fashion and issues important to Aboriginal women are all discussed. Individual women highlighted in this episode include Vida Goldstein, Muriel Heagney, Elizabeth Kenny, Dame Enid Lyons, Dame Mary Gilmore and Katherine Suzannah Pritchard.

results.title: Australian women's heritage: 1788-1901
results.brief_description: This visual history of Australian women documents the contribution of a previously overlooked group. Their work, their mothering and their civilising influence has been a major factor in Australia’s coming of age. This program begins with the daily life of Aboriginal women and also discusses issues important to these women later in the 19th Century. Also examines convict and free women; women’s contributions and life during the gold rush; fashion, education and family size, the impact of the 1890’s depression on women. Some individual women highlighted on this video are Mary Reiby, Caroline Chisholm, Louisa Lawson, Catherine Spence, Dame Nellie Melba, Mother Mary Mackillop, Truganini and Daisy Bates.

results.title: Yothu Yindi, diti murru: the videos
results.creator_credit: John Wilkinson, Martin Stauce, Stephen M Johnson, Alan James, Axolotol and Burrundi Pictures
results.brief_description: Mandawuy Yunupingu and Witiyana Marika from Yothu Yindi introduce these videos from their album “Tribal voice”. The brief introductions and the videos themselves give a simple, but telling overview of Aboriginal culture and the need for black and white society to find a common meeting place. The videos are: “Treaty”, “Mainstream”, a traditional Aboriginal dance Gudurrku = brolga”, “Treaty: Filthy Lucre mix”, “Djapana: Gapirri mix and “Tribal voice”, which encompasses a plea for all indigenous cultures to be recognised.

results.title: Call of the country
results.creator_credit: Melanie Guiney and James Cook University
results.brief_description: On remote Cape York Peninsula, the Pormpuraaw Aboriginal Community and scientists from the Anthropology and Geography departments of James Cook University are joining together to map the cultural, ecological and environmental heritage of their country. For many of the custodians it is their first trip home for many years and represents the renewal of an old and intimate relationship with the land. Through this bringing together of ancient understanding and modern methods it is hoped to preserve the past for the protection of the future.

results.title: Picture books on video. - Volume 2 = Turramulli and the giant Quinkin
results.creator_credit: Catharine Campbell, Cathy Miller and Video Classroom
results.brief_description: Three Aboriginal Dreamtime stories. “Turramulli the giant Quinkin” and “Banana Bird and the Snake men” are both written by Percy Trezise, illustrated by Dick Roughsey and narrated by Bob Maza. “The Frog and the pelican” is written by Des O’Brien. The stories are narrated with background music as the illustrations are shown on screen.

results.title: The Secret country: the first Australians fight back (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Alan Lowery and Central Independent Television (UK)
results.brief_description: According to John Pilger, “Australia is a secret country with a secret history.” This documentary looks at that history, the history of Australian First Nations peoples from the time of white settlement to the present, and reveals the extent of the cruelty and injustice inflicted upon them. The central issue throughout the film is the differing perspectives on the land and its uses, providing historical background to the present land rights movement and other areas of activism.

results.title: Fair go!
results.creator_credit: Open Channel Productions and Victorian Trades Hall Council
results.brief_description: Fair go! is a step towards meeting the needs of young people for information about their rights as workers. Using a fresh, entertaining presentation, the program follows the experiences of school-leavers Kelly and Sam, as they fall unawares into a series of near disasters in new jobs.

results.title: This is working
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, Elisabeth Knight, Film Australia and National Aboriginal Employment Development Committee
results.brief_description: Aboriginal people suffer an unemployment rate six times higher than the white community. Shows Aboriginal people in New South Wales who are working on four different job creation projects. Features, amongst others, Bill Powell, Aboriginal Liaison Officer TAFE, Rose Kirby, Murrin Bridge Handcraft Industries, Des Simon, apprentice carpenter, Purfleet and Dallas Carberry, park management trainee, Orient Point.

results.title: Highway improvements
results.brief_description: Details of planning and improvements of Victorian state highways, including climbing lanes for slow traffic, duplicate pavements, elimination of railroad crossings and development of by-pass roads.

results.title: Water birds of the inland
results.creator_credit: Lilias Fraser, Norman Castle, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Shows general feeding and nesting habits of a variety of inland water birds at Narran Lake, Western NSW (also known as Terewah Lake) and its surrounding marshy area.
